Home → Events activities → Skulduggery in Stowmarket

Skulduggery in Stowmarket

24 - 26 April

Join us for two days of talks and book signings from top crime authors. £5 per talk, £20 for a Saturday ticket or Sunday ticket, £35 for a weekend pass.

Friday 24 April

Music from Skiffuffle + support with pizza supper

1900

Come along to the launch of Skulduggery in Stowmarket 2020, featuring silly, fun skiffle kerfuffle from local band Skiffuffle and other guests.

Saturday 25 April

Rebecca Tope: Secrets in the Cotswolds

1000–1050

Rebecca Tope is the author of over 30 crime novels, set in various parts of the English countryside. The two main series are the Cotswolds series featuring Thea Osborne/Slocombe, house-sitter, and the Lake District series featuring Simmy Brown, florist. Both are amateur and often reluctant detectives.

Harry Brett: East Anglian Crime

1115–1205

Harry Brett is a pseudonym for Henry Sutton. He is the author of nine novels, including My Criminal World and Get Me Out Of Here. He also co-authored the DS Jack Frost novel, First Frost, under the pseudonym James Henry.

Louise Millar: Killer Woman

1330–1420

Louise Millar is the author of four acclaimed psychological thrillers. Her books have been published in ten countries and are Amazon Kindle bestsellers. Louise is a former senior editor of Marie Claire magazine, and the co-founder of the Killer Women crime-writing collective and the annual Killer Women Festival in London.

Jim Kelly: War & Crime - the challenge of writing a historical thriller

1445–1535

Jim Kelly is the author of 16 crime novels across three series: Philip Dryden, DI Peter Shaw and Nighthawk. His first book, The Water Clock, was shortlisted for the John Creasey Award. He has since won a CWA Dagger in the Library and the New Angle Prize for Literature.

Rory Clements: Hitler's Women

1600–1650

Rory Clements is the author of two series of historical thrillers: the John Shakespeare books, set in the late 16th century, and the Tom Wilde novels, which are largely set in and around Cambridge during the 1930s and 1940s. He has won the CWA Historical Dagger twice and has been shortlisted for several awards.

Sunday 26 April

Michael Jecks: Writing the Tudors

1000–1050

Michael Jecks is the author of 43 novels. His work encompasses his highly acclaimed Templar series of historical thrillers, his humorous Bloody Mary Tudor series, the Vintener trilogy, and a modern spy story, Act of Vengeance - described by Lee Child as ‘an instant classic British spy novel’. His books are inspired by history and legends covering the moors where he lives, but his stories are grounded in real life and real people: what motivates them, and what makes them turn to violence.

J. M. Hewitt: Using Real Life in Fiction

1115–1205

J. M. Hewitt is the author of five crime fiction novels and a member of the Crime Writers’ association. She won the BritCrime Pitch Competition 2015 and was selected as a finalist in the Twisted 50 Short Story Horror Collection 2016.

Ruth Dugdall: A Life of Crime - from probation officer to crime author

1330–1420

Ruth Dugdall is the author of seven novels, focussing of topics including human trafficking (Nowhere Girl), children who kill (Humber Boy B) and cannibalism (The Sacrificial Man). Her first novel, The Woman Before Me, won the 2005 Crime Writers’ Association Debut Dagger.

Laura Purcell: Creating Foreboding and Tension in Fiction

1445–1535

Laura Purcell is the award-winning author of three thrilling Gothic novels: The Silent Companions, The Corset, and Bone China.

Simon Brett: Tickled to Death

1600–1650

Simon Brett has published over a hundred books, many of them crime novels, including the Charles Paris, Mrs Pargeter, Fethering and Blotto & Twinks series. His stand-alone thriller, A Shock to the System, was made into a feature film, starring Michael Caine.
